p: In addition, a triterpenoid named eupulcherol A isolated from E. pulcherima was assayed for its anti-Alzheimer activity, a neurodegenerative disorder. The results revealed that the compound had promising anti-Alzheimerâ€™s disease (AD) activities and that it can inhibit the paralysis of transgenic Caenorhabditis elegans. This explains why the species were traditionally used for the treatment of hypermenorrhea, bruises, and traumatic hemorrhage [ 40].
